thread.title: Leicestershire Police detective: 'We treat seriously all reports of offensive comments on Facebook' - Leicestershire Live

author: Dan Martin
title: Leicestershire Police detective: 'We treat seriously all reports of offensive comments on Facebook' - Leicestershire Live
text:
Get Daily
The police officer who investigated a councillor for making offensive comments on Facebook say that all such reports are taken seriously.
Detective Constable Damian Young was commenting outside of court after Richard Alderman admitted using his Facebook page to call for Prime Minister Theresa May to be hanged for "treason".
The 72-year-old called for the Prime Minster's public hanging three days after being elected to Rutland County Council.
It came after he posted other grossly offensive messages about shadow home secretary Diane Abbott and Tory MP Anna Soubry.
The independent councillor - described in court as "pro-Brexit and anti-immigration" - refused to say whether he would resign his post as he left Birmingham Magistrates' Court today. Richard Alderman sent a Facebook post calling for the Prime Minister Theresa May to be hanged
The 72-year-old admitted four charges of sending a menacing or grossly offensive message via the public communication network.
They included posts describing Ms Abbott as a "monkey" and calling for Ms Soubry to be shot and drowned.
After the hearing Leicestershire Police officer DC Young said: “The content of the comments published by Alderman were deemed offensive.
"He is a prominent member of the Rutland community and should have known better as an elected councillor.
“We treat all reports of this nature seriously, irrespective of who has made them, and we’re pleased that he has admitted the offences.”
Ordering pre-sentence reports, District Judge David Robinson had told Alderman: "You have pleaded guilty to these four charges and you will receive credit for that in due course." Like us on Facebook
